item.title: Internal Terms
item.description:
These are internal terms that should be aware of that should inform your knowledge about projects. Bellow is a list of business ideas like Platforms, Technical Stacks, or Domains The American College of Cardiology (ACC) is a US-based global nonprofit medical society dedicated to transforming cardiovascular care and improving heart health. Founded in 1949, it serves as a professional home for cardiovascular clinicians by advancing education, clinical standards, and policy initiatives while also leading efforts in quality improvement, advocacy, and research dissemination. ACC‚Äôs membership includes more than 56,000 professionals worldwide, representing a diverse mix of cardiologists, cardiovascular surgeons, nurses, physician assistants, pharmacists, researchers, and other health professionals. Members span across all career stages, from medical students and trainees to senior practitioners and international experts. This broad member base fosters collaboration, mentorship, and the exchange of knowledge across the spectrum of cardiovascular medicine.`[Business Lines (BL)] - Education, Science & Quality, Membership - Define needs, goals, and priorities | v [MarCom (Marketing & Communications)] - Sets brand voice, graphics, and final text | v [EDCS (Enterprise Digital Content Strategy)] - Product Owners: define vision, manage backlog, align strategy - UX Designers: ensure usability, accessibility, and design consistency | v [Web Production] - Executes in Sitecore/Sitefinity - Applies Arches Patterns, formats, publishes, ensures repeatability | v [IT (Technology & Development)] - Developers (back end, front end, full stack) - Build, integrate, optimize, and maintain platforms | v [ACC Digital Experiences] - Branded, functional, user-focused platforms and products BLs drive what needs to be done. MarCom defines how it should look and sound. EDCS interprets and organizes the vision into digital strategies. Web Production executes updates and content in the CMS. IT provides the technical foundation and ensures long-term stability. The output is a cohesive digital experience aligned with ACC‚Äôs mission. A Product Owner in EDCS defines the vision, priorities, and roadmap for digital products. They manage backlogs, translate business goals into actionable work, and ensure delivery aligns with both user needs and organizational strategy. Acting as the bridge between stakeholders, developers, and designers, they represent the customer voice while ensuring measurable outcomes. Within ACC, Product Owners work closely with UX Designers, MarCom, and IT to deliver consistent, value-driven digital experiences that reflect both user requirements and enterprise goals.A UX Designer in EDCS ensures digital experiences are accessible, clear, and user-focused. They conduct research, map journeys, and create prototypes or wireframes to streamline usability. UX Designers balance user needs with business objectives and work closely with Product Owners to ensure products meet goals. Their designs apply Arches Patterns consistently, creating repeatable experiences across platforms. At ACC, UX is central to making digital tools intuitive while ensuring the broader MarCom brand voice is faithfully translated into functional, engaging designs.Web Production staff manage page creation and updates in Sitecore or Sitefinity. With basic HTML knowledge and Arches Pattern usage, their work emphasizes accuracy, repeatability, and consistency. They implement content and design direction provided by EDCS and MarCom while ensuring CMS workflows remain efficient and reliable. Web Producers handle formatting, publishing, and troubleshooting common issues. Serving as the operational layer of digital delivery, they translate strategy, design, and content decisions into live experiences that remain on-brand and technically stable.Business Lines (BLs) represent core ACC departments such as Education, Science and Quality, or Membership. Each BL manages its portfolio of programs, services, and products, setting priorities and outcomes while collaborating with EDCS, MarCom, Web Production, and IT. BLs ensure offerings remain financially sustainable, strategically aligned, and meaningful to members. Their decisions provide direction on what needs to be built or updated, while other divisions ensure execution. This structure enables BLs to focus on subject matter expertise while leveraging enterprise teams for delivery.MarCom shapes the voice, brand, and visual identity of the ACC. They provide final approval on text, tone, and graphics across campaigns and digital properties, ensuring consistency and authority. MarCom defines the broad brand direction and messaging, while EDCS translates it into digital execution. Their oversight ensures that outputs are polished, professional, and aligned with the ACC‚Äôs mission. In partnership with BLs, Web Production, and IT, MarCom ensures that every communication‚Äîwhether print or digital‚Äîreinforces the college‚Äôs trusted, global brand identity.The IT division brings together developers across back-end, front-end, and full-stack disciplines to design, build, and maintain ACC‚Äôs digital infrastructure. This team ensures platforms like Sitecore, Sitefinity, and custom systems are stable, scalable, and secure. IT works closely with EDCS and Web Production to implement features, troubleshoot issues, and deliver technical enhancements. Specialized developers also support integration with external systems and performance optimization. As the technical foundation of digital projects, IT enables innovation while ensuring compliance, reliability, and long-term sustainability of ACC‚Äôs platforms. ACC.org is the official website of the American College of Cardiology. It serves as a comprehensive resource for cardiology professionals, offering a wide range of content including clinical updates, educational materials, guidelines, and information on cardiology conferences and events. The site is designed to support medical professionals in the field of cardiology with the latest scientific research, policy advocacy, and continuous education. It also provides tools and resources for practice support, quality improvement, and patient care in the cardiovascular field. The website caters to the needs of cardiologists, providing them with essential information to advance their knowledge and practice. This Domain is built on the CMS of Sitecore.
CardioSmart.org is a patient-centered website created by the American College of Cardiology. It provides comprehensive information about heart health and various cardiac conditions. The site is dedicated to educating patients, offering resources on heart diseases, healthy living tips, and tools to manage cardiac health. It includes topics such as heart disease prevention, treatment options, and lifestyle changes. CardioSmart.org is designed to empower patients with knowledge and tools to actively participate in their own heart care and make informed decisions about their health. This Domain is built on the CMS of SiteFinity.
CVQuality.acc.org serves as a hub for the ACC Quality Improvement for Institutions Program, catering primarily to healthcare professionals who focus on quality improvements and administration rather than direct clinical practice. It offers resources and initiatives like NCDR registries, accreditation services, and clinical toolkits aimed at enhancing cardiovascular care quality. The site provides valuable support and tools for healthcare facilities to implement evidence-based practices and engage in quality improvement projects, aligning with the administrative and quality improvement aspects of healthcare.
https://www.jacc.org/ The Journal of the American College of Cardiology (JACC) is the flagship peer-reviewed journal of the ACC and one of the most influential publications in cardiovascular medicine. Ranked among the top journals in the field, JACC publishes cutting-edge research, clinical trials, expert reviews, and practice guidelines that shape cardiovascular practice worldwide. It is part of the broader JACC Family of Journals, which cover subspecialties such as heart failure, imaging, intervention, electrophysiology, and basic science.
ARCHES is a comprehensive front-end design system by the American College of Cardiology. It uses advanced compiler techniques to generate variations that integrate with different frameworks and brands, making it versatile for various ACC products. ARCHES primarily consists of utility classes that offer a modern approach to CSS, focusing on single-style control and separation of responsibilities between HTML and CSS. This system is flexible and adaptable, used across multiple ACC platforms, including ACC.org and CardioSmart, and supports distinct brand styles while maintaining overall coherence. This solution uses NPM, SCSS, and KSS framework to produce the documentation which is hosted here https://assets.acc.org/Arches/Latest/docs/. ARCHES Bespoke is a set of micro style sheets when a solution is very specialized and the styles are not appropriate to add to the overhead of all pages and it is need for a focused specialized usage.
PaperCrane refers to a Component Library specifically designed for Vue.js, a progressive JavaScript framework. This library is utilized in the development of Single Page Applications (SPAs). PaperCrane contains a collection of pre-built Vue components which can be reused across different parts of the enterprise application, enhancing development speed and ensuring UI consistency. This project is built with Storybook and is hosted here https://assets.acc.org/papercrane/Latest/docs/?path=/story/paper-crane--page ONECRM is a an effort to move our CRM(Customer Relationship Management Software) from Personify to Salesforce. This is a multi year effort and is complex collaboration of setting up Salesforce to fit the needs of ACC. It is also an effort of updating API, User Experience Flows, Integrations, Solutions, and Content across our digital platforms. Products that are majorly effected is the Shopping Cart that used to be Ebiz now Salesforce. Membership Application from OMA to Salesforce, and Membership Management. HubSpot is a email services. The HubSpot platform is starting to be positioned to house "Marketing Landing Pages". These pages are are directly connected to a marketing campaign, they do not have extensive connections or navigation paths from any of our Domains, and they are also time box and have a limited lifespan.

item.title: Future of UX Presentation
Project Description
item.description: Guideline Algorithm Design SystemThe Guideline Algorithm Design System was a collaborative effort between Matt, Rowena, and Lauren P., aimed at transforming the way clinical algorithms are presented within ACC guidelines.Previously, algorithm visuals lacked consistency and clarity‚Äîresulting in designs that were often difficult to follow or visually fractured. This project brought structure and coherence by introducing a comprehensive set of design standards, visual language, and reusable assets. The system empowers the Guidelines team to create algorithms that are easier to read, understand, and implement in clinical practice.A key enhancement was the introduction of a new color palette designed for accessibility. The updated palette ensures higher contrast ratios for better on-screen readability and preserves meaning when printed in black-and-white‚Äîcritical for clinicians who rely on hard copies or monochrome prints.This redesign was informed by research conducted two years ago(focus groups by Rowena and Surveys by everyone) at the Annual Scientific Session, which showed that while ACC‚Äôs algorithms were trusted for their accuracy, ESC‚Äôs were more widely used due to their visual appeal. Our goal was to close that gap‚Äîand exceed it‚Äîby making our algorithms not just accurate, but also engaging and user-friendly.After a year of workshops and refinement, the finalized system is now being implemented. Lauren P. is currently applying it to the forthcoming HBP Guideline, which will be the first to fully reflect this new visual and structural standard.This has resulted in improved capturing from workgroups who are now using it. Positive feedback from the review committees.   And the post production vendors have remarked a faster to market production time to  make interactives from the algorithms.

item.title: Strategic Glossary of Page Concepts in ACC.org
item.description:
Page Concept Types ‚ë† Home Page
‚ë° Concept Anchors
‚ë¢ Initiatives (Goal-Oriented Modules)
‚ë£ Product Groupings
‚ë§ Product Destinations (Transactional Pages)
‚ë• Standard Pages
‚ë¶ Listing Pages Information Architecture
How These Pages Associate with Each Other
General I.A. Guidelines The main entry point of the website, designed to provide immediate orientation, highlight major initiatives, latest updates, and guide users quickly toward primary goals. Use Case: First-time visitors, returning users seeking major updates, initial brand impression. Why Used: Creates immediate clarity and positions organizational priorities upfront. Branding & UI Elements: Take over, Hero Image, Feature Triptych... Role in IA: The central entry point. Highest-level orientation, connecting users quickly and intuitively to key site sections. Prioritizes major pathways, brand introduction, and timely highlights. Rules & Recommendations: Use clearly defined navigation to major Concept Anchors and prioritized user tasks. Limit content to essential items for quick user orientation (less is more). Regularly update to reflect organizational priorities and timely initiatives. When to Use: Always present as the top-level entry page. Avoid: Do not overload with detailed content or overly transactional messaging.
Pages offering high-level overviews of the organization's core concepts, primary service areas, or central offerings. They orient users by clearly presenting a broader narrative or theme. Example Page: About US Use Case: Navigation entry points for broad organizational topics, connecting various subpages and initiatives. Why Used: Humanizes the organization, reinforces brand values, and simplifies access to deeper content.
Branding & UI Elements: Concept Hero with Feature, Grid Bento, UL Icon Text List of Icon ULs, Grouping Zones, Section Shading Role in IA: Provide clear, user-friendly overviews for broad organizational pillars. Anchor navigation to strategic themes. Introduce voice, tone, and topic landscape. Rules & Recommendations: Connect to Initiatives, Product Groupings, and Standard Pages. Reflect organization-wide narratives or verticals. Avoid overwhelming detail‚Äîkeep it narrative and directional. When to Use: When multiple related initiatives or products are associated with a central idea. Avoid: Don‚Äôt use for deeply detailed or transactional content.
Targeted microsites or sections devoted to specific organizational efforts or campaigns, often incorporating unique branding or visual differentiation. These modules are action-focused, with clearly defined user goals Example Page: Advocacy | UX Use Case: Advocacy, fundraising, campaigns, accreditation explanation. Why Used: Enhances clarity of purpose, supports targeted user journeys, simplifies complex messaging.
Branding & UI Elements: Microsite Hero Banner, Secondary Action Card, Cards, Icon & Content Grid List, Grouping Zones, Section Shading Role in IA: Specific journeys with clear purpose and outcome. Often stand apart structurally or visually. Internal navigation can be isolated from the main site to support clearer marketing language, simplified instructions, and more targeted messaging. Rules & Recommendations: Must articulate the purpose and offer a focused action. Allow for deviation in branding when needed. Link from Concept Anchors or Home Page. When to Use: When a program has a goal, outcome, and distinct message. Avoid: Avoid for purely informational content or where cohesion with parent content is critical. item.title: X-Axis Unique Content
item.description: <-- Back to Data(from Fully Duplicated to Fully Distinct) -4: Fully Duplicated The main site republishes journal content directly, with minimal or no modification. There‚Äôs heavy content recycling in different formats (e.g., blog posts, highlights, infographics). -2: Featured Cross-Publication Journal content is regularly spotlighted on the main site through excerpts, featured articles, or summaries. There‚Äôs a clear editorial flow from journal to main. -1: Light Journal Echoing Occasional journal content appears on the main site‚Äîselect articles or issues are highlighted in news sections or as updates. 0: Reference Integration The main site discusses the journal broadly, possibly with multiple references or deep links, but does not reuse actual content. +1: Deep Link Framing The main site promotes its journal through deep links to individual issues or articles, but without embedding or echoing the content itself. +2: Journal Link Presence The main site acknowledges the journal‚Äôs existence and links to it (usually at a high level like ‚ÄúOur Journal‚Äù), but without further editorial emphasis or content reuse. +3: Minimal Journal Exposure Journal presence is limited to a basic link or navigation tab. item.title: X-Axis Audience Focus
item.description: <-- Back to Data(from Narrow/Insider-Focused to Fully Inclusive) -4: Hyper-Specialized Professionals Content is designed for a narrow expert audience within a medical subspecialty (e.g., electrophysiologists, heart failure specialists). item.title: Web Based Heuristics
item.description: Ensure the site provides immediate feedback for user actions, such as logging in, submitting forms, or loading pages, so users know their actions are being processed. The content and navigation should use terms and language that resonate with your audience (e.g., "My Courses," "Membership Dashboard," "Explore Articles") to make the site intuitive. Users should be able to easily navigate between sections, undo actions, and go back without confusion, especially when managing membership details or course enrollments. The design, layout, and labeling should remain consistent across the site, whether users are in the membership area, reading articles, or accessing educational content. Provide users with clear, guided steps to minimize mistakes, particularly in processes like signing up for a membership, enrolling in a course, or making a purchase. Reduce the need for users to remember details by displaying key information clearly, such as membership status, progress in courses, and recommended articles. Design for both new and experienced users, allowing shortcuts and advanced features (like filtering or bookmarking) for members who visit frequently while keeping it simple for new visitors. Ensure that pages are visually simple and easy to navigate, focusing on the most important actions like reading articles, accessing courses, or checking membership benefits. If something goes wrong, provide a clear explanation and actionable steps to resolve the issue, such as payment problems or content loading errors. Ensure that users can quickly find help through FAQs, support articles, or a contact option, especially when they are having trouble with their membership, accessing courses, or reading content.

item.title: Member Sections Presentation Script
item.description: Presentation of Member SectionsThe future design of Member Sections operates on a simple tenant: showcase value while giving the user actionable steps to access that value. The design decisions to follow are to build the foundation of the experience.Member sections are an exclusive space tailored to capture resources, tools, and opportunities to engage in mentoring and/or gain pathways to leadership.   ‚Äã‚ÄãTo support this, we established a new dynamic and personalized onboarding process to meet users where they are rather than giving them instructions that cover what could be a multiple-week ordeal to gain access. At every step, we want to showcase to users what they are missing out on. We intend to reward the users by opening up specialized areas in Docmatter and curating exclusive content behind the access walls.Let's dive into some of the details. When talking about onboarding, we want to consider 4 user states: ‚Äã LOGGED OUT NOT A MEMBER OF THE COLLEGE A MEMBER WHO DOESN'T HAVE ACCESS TO THE SECTION A USER WITH FULL ACCESS.‚Äã ‚ÄãThese personalization hooks give us the flexibility to craft the experience, allowing for better instructions and selling tactics.Only users of a specific state are shown the next steps in their personalized journey. ‚Äã This allows us to craft the upsell and instructions to Membership for example or the Member Section when the time is appropriate.Now that the onboarding process has become simplified in messaging and action, we can discuss how our users are often part of more than one section. To reduce mental friction when moving from one section to another, we want to strongly enforce consistency.‚Äã This consistency can been seen in the design pattern, the layouts and more importantly the labels and page structures. ‚Äã This will allow our multifaceted members to experience an organized environment so they can focus on the content rather than where it was labeled or placed. An added benefit is that when new features are rolled out, they are easier to discover.‚ÄãPersonalization will not be added to just the main page. The content zones of sections will also showcase content at different levels keyed to the user's access. This can showcase the quality of materials and enforce a desire to gain full access to this quality content.

item.title: Quality of life configurations with Sitecore
item.description: Considering the difficulties that editors encounter in distinguishing between legacy, converted, and legacy supportive components, owing to the absence of folder structure and clear naming, we've introduced a streamlined approach. All component icons are now set to grey or red by default. However, converted and supportive components, along with the majority of new work, will be marked with either blue icons for compatible renderings or green for new arches components. This blue color is intended to be the default setting both arches and legacy supportive components. It's essential for the development team to review and ensure this default setting when releasing new work into the platform. In any instance where the blue green or grey is not the icon for the rending, the setting must be promptly corrected. Further Icon Definition allow for even easier recognition in the back end will be. Page Layout components should be Starts, Vue/JavaScript driven components should be puzzle pieces. When looking at the display view list in the backend you only see the render name and its relative location that it is placed in the list. As the teams move forward in using more and more shared content and breaking down content into chunks the Display view gets rather unusable because you would see RichText written possibly 5 times on the page the same is true with accordions. In that view is it possible to interject at least the details of the source which can be altered with a nickname like intro-text, benefit grid.....The component dependency tree outlines the interrelationships between components in a Sitecore instance, specifically identifying those that are either children of a component or have dependent child components. Only necessary components should be configured in this instance to maintain simplicity and reduce confusion for editors. This approach also minimizes the risk of including non-supportive components by lessening the need for editors to manually add components. Ultimately, this method aids in preventing the appearance of non-supportive components within converted pages, ensuring a clean and efficient working environment.

item.title: Refactors
item.description:
A Refactor project at ACC.org focuses on systematically restructuring, optimizing, or modernizing a specific area of our digital ecosystem without altering its core functionality. The goal is to improve maintainability, performance, accessibility, and long-term sustainability while aligning with best practices in development, content management, and user experience.This process often involves: Code Optimization: Enhancing front-end and back-end code to improve efficiency, reduce technical debt, and ensure compliance with modern standards. Content Restructuring: Reviewing and reorganizing digital content within Sitecore or Sitefinity to streamline navigation, improve searchability, and eliminate redundancies. Design & UX Enhancements: Refining layouts, typography, and interaction patterns for better usability while maintaining consistency with ACC‚Äôs design systems, such as ARCHES and PaperCrane. Performance Improvements: Optimizing page load times, reducing server requests, and implementing caching strategies to enhance user experience. Integration & API Updates: Ensuring seamless connectivity between ACC.org, CRM systems (ONECRM), and external platforms (HubSpot, analytics tools). SEO & Analytics Refinement: Updating metadata, link structures, and tracking mechanisms to improve visibility and data accuracy. Each Refactor initiative is data-driven, with preliminary audits and analytics reports guiding decisions. The ultimate objective is to create a scalable, future-proof solution that enhances both user experience and backend manageability while preserving existing content and functionality. item.title: Outline of Tickets for SPAs in Vue
item.description: Single Page Applications Ticket kicks all of this off Design and Requirements Technical Feasibility Design Iteration Follow Up from Technical Feasibility Basic Application: Data & API Basic Application: Page Construction, Code Branch, Page Access Basic Application: Vue APP SHELL Basic Application: Application Initiation. Component Construction: 1 ‚Äì Many Tickets Application Specifics | Feature X scaffolding: 1 ‚Äì Many Tickets Application Integration with Components | Feature X Refinement with QA: 1 ‚Äì Many Tickets These types of tickets come in phases where many of the branches can work in partnership moving the designed application forward with some autonomy.These tickets are iterative and often are labeled the ‚ÄúSprint 0‚Äù depending on the ask from the product owner and how developed the concept is before the team receives the project this will be iterative. Often this should be a set of meetings and reviews between the UX Team and Technical Architect and Front-End Senior Lead with responses sent back to the UX team and ultimately the Product Owner. Depending on how ‚ÄúLean‚Äù you want to run the project this can be as lean as a rough sketch where the particulars are hashed out in the project to full-blown comps with requirement notes being captured in the Parent ‚ÄúEpic‚Äù Ticket. Initial talks of analytics should be talked about prompt the BL to reach out to the analytics team to establish this branch of the requirements.When the receiving team is comfortable with the clarity of the intended product this phase will break down the ask into dispersible tickets. Depending on the skill and resources these tickets can be sized appropriately for the team. Basic Application Construction can start on day one considering the scaffolding is fundamental to any other work.Independent work is brought together in this phase. It is common that co-working and JAD sessions occur in these tickets as team members bring together the individual efforts. There is no clean break of this phase to previous depending on the delivery it is common that a feature might go through all phases and be QA‚Äôd before other features are even started.Design Phase is the most prone to change. This phase should be mostly completed before the rest of the tasks should start. There is always reason, technical or just iterating over an experience that can cause changes to the design but if the team has a good idea of what is being built and rework will be reduced. The tenants of AGILE does allow for iteration so it is inevitable that rework or alteration will happen. Documenting for the team should migrate to comments on design documents because living design documents are costly and in the end are a non-production artifact. It is very important that the Technology Team (DEV & UI Lead) break down the steps and familiarize themselves with the nuances of the features to intelligently question the design and highlight possible issues before alterations become more impactful to the timelines. QA at this point can even scaffold out User Tests on features during this step.Team review of the UX design of Project X. Highlight and Flag and Feasibility Changes and Iterate over them with the UX team. Team will submit a scaffolding of tickets to produce the Application. Details should include Data needs, Implementation Specifics, Analytics definitions, and Front-End Breakdown.These steps are mostly dependent on the previous and could be collapsed to a single ticket but the ambiguity of the Data API it is best to keep these tickets into separate tickets to utilize a wider base of resources.API & Data Structures to support the application outline the data handshake and return results for App Build Team & UI Team.A user may only visit the URL if the user is logged in. The page will do all needed steps to redirect the user through log in in needed and redirect the user back to the page after success. Define URL & create the hosting page in Sitecore.A user should be able to visit a URL and have an application on that page respond to the visitor with the information it has available to it. Create the shell of the application and establish needed hooks to the data the application will know. This information is defined by the project but in the most basic definitions the application will know about the User, and possibly the URL and any query structures.When the user visits the application, and it is loaded the application will initiate and collect information through API calls to store any data that is needed to display information and formulate any actions needed for the user defined by the project.Components should follow the single tenant that they are only responsible for data passed to them and emitting their context. This separates concerns when the Application takes most of the features and components can stay agnostic.When creating components all new components will be created with the library‚Äôs project folder. If the team finds value for a specific component that is generic enough to be reusable across many applications, the component can be promoted to a common library folder. Be aware that common components require a greater level of flexibility and scope to make them bullet proof for generic consumption.Component tickets should encompass basic mutations that are needed for that component. Basic examples or mutations are Size, Location or Inclusion, Props (Data they will display), Validations, States, Etc. This should result in a Code Review and a Demo with UX Team and Product Owner. To reduce meeting overload, they can be grouped with other tickets or be deferred to the Feature Refinement TicketThe user should be able to see the data they need to see and interact with data as defined by the requirements this is known as feature. In many cases features can be scaffolded with their data and methods without the need of utilizing components. Operations of an application like looping, reductions, additions, removals, data hooks and server responses can be all worked out without the use of components.User should be able to do X Feature. For Example, ‚Äúscaffold delete this line item from the list.‚Äù This will produce a data storage, list and methods and listeners that can be used to remove data from the list. This would also include any database API and deal with the response return updating the stored data of the list.Inclusion of components and refinement of the frontend features. These phases will ‚Äúwire‚Äù data and properties to components into the application. Depending on the size of the application these can be broken down into Features, or Pages, or States. This is the moment where components are due from the front-end teams. The deployment of components can be more staggered if the team is more comfortable with constant deployments. The benefits of this would be a lister would be available much earlier in the development process but may need to be updated or rewired if changes to validation or data needs alter in the refinement process.User should be able to do X Feature in the AppFor Example, ‚ÄúA user by clicking on the delete button on a list item should delete it from the list.‚Äù Render a data list with the delete button. On the click add a listener to the application that will trigger the delete feature that has been scaffolded. QA this feature. Demo this Feature with UX Team and Product Owner.

A microsite, also known as brochure pages, is an independent yet intergrated subsection within the main ACC.org framework. Microsites must have an established goal to be considered to be broken away from the main Acc.org framework. A clearly defined central focus and goal, the microsite serves as a concentrated platform for strategic communication and user interaction. This grouping of pages includes the basic branding of the main site while introducing: unique sub-branding elements, a sandboxed navigation structure. These components establish a distinct identity, subtly differentiating the microsite while preserving coherence with the main brand. The structuring of the microsite comprises multiple interconnected pages that form an exclusive navigation tree. This enclosed network ensures that each page links exclusively to other pages within the microsite, creating a tailored, immersive user journey. TLDR Quick Read Microsite: A distinct, yet cohesive, self-contained subsection within the ACC.org site. Sub Branding Elements: Unique branding features that distinguish the microsite from the main ACC.org brand, yet align with its basic branding. Enclosed Navigation Tree: The microsite encompasses a network of pages that interlink exclusively within its own scope, creating a customized navigation experience. item.title: Full Page Splashes (Hubspot)
item.description:
Full Page Splashes, orphan pages, or marketing landing pages are isolated pages within our website's architecture that are not linked from the homepage and should be used sparingly and strategically. These pages exist outside of our website's primary navigation and can inadvertently disrupt a user's browsing experience. As a rule, these pages should only be created in specific scenarios - such as part of a well-defined marketing campaign with a predetermined lifespan.Before implementing a Full Page Splash, ensure all of the following criteria are met: The page is directly tied to a specific marketing campaign. #checklist
The page has a limited lifespan with a clearly established takedown date. #checklist
The page is structured within the Sitecore folder, specifically under Parent of Main Branch/features. #checklist
The content is succinct enough to fit on a single page without overwhelming the user. #checklist
The content is not intended to be organically discovered from the main site, and does not contribute to the overall SEO strategy. #checklist
All intended conversion points are a single click away. ‚Üí Buy, Register, etc... #checklist
Contacted the Analytics team in EDS to provide the user flow funneling that should be tracked and the defined markers for success. #checklist
Assess the potential impact on user experience. Ensure that the Full Page Splash aligns with the user journey and does not disrupt it. #checklist
Review the content strategy to ensure that the Full Page Splash complements it, rather than creating dissonance. #checklist
Evaluate the necessity of a Full Page Splash versus incorporating the content into the existing site structure. #checklist
Plan for future content updates or potential expansions. Will this information always be relevant as a standalone page or should it be integrated into the main site later? #checklist By sticking to these guidelines, we can maintain a cohesive, user-friendly, and purposeful website that aligns with our overall content strategy.There might be strategically valuable reasons to hook our Landing Pages being hosted on our email service so we could gain benefits of technology isolation, and built in Analytics.

item.title: Project Build Outline
item.description: Subject: Exciting Opportunity: Redesigning Member SectionsDear Team,As we embark on the transformative journey of redesigning our Member Sections, I want to share an overview of our strategic process and the essential tasks that will lead to our success. This initiative, commencing after the Annual Meeting in April 2025, involves over twenty sections and will require our collective effort to achieve outstanding consistency and quality.Leading up to April 2025, Jackie, Laura, and I will concentrate on several key tasks to establish a solid foundation: Proof of Concept (POC): We will finalize a robust WIC POC to define our preferred tone, brevity, and structure. This benchmark will guide all pages and content styles. Content Access Guidelines: After cleaning up existing content, Jackie and I will draft clear guidelines delineating public-facing content from that exclusive to members. We'll circulate this initial draft to the Tiger team for insights. IT Development Planning: Armed with the POC, we will collaborate with leadership to outline and align on our anticipated IT development requirements for dynamic content and and the user onboarding logic. Content and Resources Collection: Our team will create an effective initiation script and a user-friendly content collection form to streamline the content-gathering process for our liaisons. This groundwork will empower us to seamlessly engage with staff liaisons following the Annual Meeting.Content collection for our Member Sections is scheduled to begin in April 2025. To optimize our resources, we will prioritize which sections to revamp first. Kickoff Meeting/Workshop: We will introduce the dedicated project team and the creative assets needed for content collection. Matt and Jackie will lead a workshop to showcase an illustrative section while demonstrating the collection form. Content Collection Responsibilities: Each section team will undertake the content collection and refactoring, utilizing the WIC POC as their guide. Our oversight will ensure alignment and quality throughout the process. Completion of Content: Once content is gathered, our coordination team will collaborate with MarCom to generate essential images for prominent features. Quality Assurance: A JIRA ticket will be created to document the creation of the newly refactored Member Section, ensuring transparency and tracking. Editorial Review: Based on our priorities, the completed section will be processed, entered into Author, reviewed, and then published for production. Repeat for All Sections: This process will be repeated systematically for all remaining sections. Early 2025: Finalize the POC, establish clear content guidelines, plan IT development, and prepare liaison resources. Post-Annual Meeting (April 2025): Launch engagement with liaisons and section teams to kick off content collection. item.title: Algorithm Read Me
item.description: The file includes all the necessary assets to create guideline algorithms, ensuring consistency across all designs. To maintain the established design system, use the provided color swatches, Illustrator panels, and graphic, character, and paragraph styles.These design enforcements support a consistent experience and are reader-focused, making the algorithms easy to read, understand, and provide valuable information like the CORs (Class of Recommendation). The algorithm is mostly monochromatic, with a focus on high contrast separation between the background and text to improve readability. COR colors are used specifically to highlight important information, ensuring that critical details stand out for the reader. Node and Decision Symbols: Always use the predefined symbols for nodes and decisions. These symbols are already designed to align with the correct COR color and shape, ensuring that each element is visually consistent and recognizable. Line and Label Symbols: Use the predefined line and label symbols to maintain consistent visual direction and clarity. Lines such as "YES," "NO," and the avoid markers are standardized for effective communication. Node Binders: Use symbols like NODE BINDER -- AND, NODE BINDER -- OR, and NODE BINDER -- ANY to represent logical connections between nodes clearly. This ensures that all decision junctions are presented in a consistent manner. Line Styles: Lines connecting nodes are styled consistently with arrows indicating the direction of flow. There are no variations in line thickness. Text Alignment: Text within each node should be aligned to the left and vertically centered to enhance readability. Legend Placement: Place the legend in the top right corner by default. If there is insufficient space, use the bottom right, followed by the bottom left. Legends should never be placed in the top left. Refer to the finished example to understand how these elements work together to create a consistent and branded algorithm design.The Illustrator file is set up with an artboard named "Toolkit," which contains all the essential elements for designing guideline algorithms. This toolkit includes: Symbols: Predefined symbols such as data nodes, decision shapes, and other graphic elements. Graphic Styles: Graphic Styles are used for line styles and arrows, applying the consistent look and feel to lines and arrows based on a simple line in Illustrator. Character Styles: The character styles in the file include options for titles, labels, node content, and more. Use the Title style for main headings, Zone Label for section labels, and Node Regular or Node Strong for content within nodes. There are also specific styles for COR Labels to ensure that Class of Recommendation values stand out appropriately. Paragraph Styles: Utilize the Paragraph Styles to maintain consistency across body text and labels. For instance, use Node Text for text within nodes and Footnotes for any additional information provided at the bottom of the algorithm. The Line Labels style ensures all directional labels (e.g., "YES," "NO") are clearly formatted. Color Swatches: The approved color palette for decision points and node types. Toolkit Artboard: Refer to the toolkit artboard to quickly access and apply these elements. Use the Toolkit: Start by using the elements provided in the toolkit artboard to maintain consistency. Smart Alignment: Use smart guides to align elements properly, ensuring nodes align in the same column for a clean and professional layout. Apply Character and Paragraph Styles: Always use the predefined character and paragraph styles to ensure that text formatting is consistent. This includes titles, labels, footnotes, and node content. Consistent use of styles helps maintain a reader-friendly experience and aligns with branding standards.

item.title: CCKE Content Proposal
item.description: This is an audit of the two Product Pages that currently have overlapping content. Below is a numbered list of the two pages, and how they will be referred to thereafter: Certified Cardiovascular Knowledge Examination (CCKE) For NPs/PAs Practicing in the U.S.: a. Referred to as CVTeam. Certified Cardiovascular Knowledge Examination (CCKE) For Physicians Practicing Outside the U.S.: a. Referred to as Clinician-OUS. The two pages‚Äî"CVTEAM" and "Clinician-OUS"‚Äîcontain significant overlap and some type-specific content. The recommendations below aim to streamline and unify both pages for clarity and ease of navigation for users. Content can be categorized into three groups: identical, very similar, and type-specific. The goal is to consolidate identical content, modify the similar content to fit both groups where applicable, and keep type-specific information targeted to the specific audience. Unify Duplicate Sections: Many sections across both pages have the same or nearly identical content, such as "How Will the Exam be Administered?", "What is the Reliability of This Exam?", and "What Topics Are Included on This Exam?". Consolidate these into one central resource (such as a FAQ) that is shared between both audiences. Keep Persona-Specific Details Separate: Type-specific content should be kept separate where necessary to ensure that information remains relevant and directly applicable to each audience, e.g., "Who's Eligible to Take ACC's Certified Cardiovascular Knowledge Examination (CCKE)?" where eligibility criteria differ for NPs/PAs versus physicians. Create Cross-References to Simplify Navigation: Provide hyperlinks between shared sections and persona-specific pages to make it easier for users to navigate between general and specific content. This will improve the overall user journey by reducing the likelihood of confusion between similar content. The proposed AI structure helps streamline the content by focusing each page's role to enhance user experience, reduce redundancy, and provide clear navigation pathways even when users arrive at the wrong page variant. Product Page: Centralizes key exam-related content, making it the first point of reference for all users. It focuses on eligibility, application processes, exam administration, and a general overview, ensuring consistency and reducing noise by keeping shared content unified. Persona Detail Pages: Targeted at specific roles, these pages provide tailored details for eligibility, exam dates, preparation resources, and other specifics. By keeping type-specific information on dedicated pages, users can easily navigate to content relevant to their background without sifting through unrelated details. FAQ Page: Acts as a shared resource for questions that apply to both personas. This page will address common concerns, minimizing redundancy and providing a quick, centralized place for users to find general information. Hyperlinks will be used to direct users to persona-specific details where necessary. This structure is designed to help users who might have arrived at the wrong variant by guiding them to the right section, thus reducing user frustration and improving satisfaction.Consolidation of Identical and Very Similar Content: Move sections that are largely duplicated to a shared FAQ or product page. These sections include "How Will the Exam be Administered?", "What is the Reliability of This Exam?", and "Does the CCKE Offer a Credential?" Doing so will help reduce maintenance efforts while also improving consistency for users. Maintaining Persona-Specific Content: For sections that are specific to either "Clinician-OUS" or "CVTeam," create separate Persona Detail Pages. For instance, eligibility requirements, submission details, and exam dates vary between the two audiences. Keeping these sections separate but cross-referencing shared content will reduce confusion while allowing both pages to provide specialized information. Use of Accordion Components: Keep the collapsible accordion structure to allow users to access content in manageable portions, making the pages less overwhelming. Ensure that each accordion component has consistent headings and styles across both "CVTeam" and "Clinician-OUS" pages. Navigation Enhancements: To further reduce confusion, provide clear links at the end of shared sections like "How Much Does This Exam Cost?" to direct users to persona-specific details. If the two products cannot be merged, it is recommended to rebrand one or both products to ensure they are distinguishable and reduce confusion. The proposed rebranding involves the following: Certified Cardiovascular Knowledge Examination (CCKE) for NPs/PAs Practicing in the U.S. (CVTeam): Maintain existing branding, but emphasize that this version of the exam is specifically for U.S.-based Nurse Practitioners and Physician Assistants. Certified Cardiovascular Knowledge Examination (CCKE) for Physicians Practicing Outside the U.S. (Clinician-OUS): Rebrand this product to differentiate it more clearly from CVTeam. Consider adding a geographic or professional distinction to the name, such as "International Cardiovascular Knowledge Certification" or "Certified Cardiovascular Competence for International Physicians". Visual and Structural Distinction: Introduce distinct color schemes or visual markers on both product pages to signal the difference at a glance. Update headers and footers to clearly mention the audience for each product, e.g., "For Physicians Practicing Outside the U.S." vs. "For U.S.-based Nurse Practitioners and Physician Assistants". Clarify Naming Across All Communications: Update all marketing, email, and support documentation to ensure that users are consistently seeing the rebranded names. Ensure that cross-references between the products are explicit about the intended audience to avoid any ambiguity. The goal of the rebranding effort is to reduce confusion, particularly among members who may be unsure which certification is appropriate for their professional background. By creating a stronger distinction between the two certifications, ACC can improve user satisfaction and reduce the potential for misapplication.

item.title: Maximize Conversions with Integrated Marketing
item.description:
Email MarketingHere‚Äôs a streamlined process flow for utilizing Direct Marketing Emails, Social Posts, and Web Marketing to drive users to landing pages with single goal CTAs, optimizing for conversion: Objective: Whether the goal is membership sign-up, promoting a specific product, or encouraging course enrollment, start with a clear and single-focused goal. Audience Segmentation: Use member data to segment your audience (e.g., new vs. existing members, product preferences, or education needs). Tailor your messaging accordingly.
Personalized Messaging: Send segmented, targeted emails based on member interest or product interaction. Use personalized subject lines and content to engage the recipient. Single CTA Focus: Keep the email concise, focusing on one action‚Äîwhether it's signing up for membership, taking a course, or learning more about a product. Visual Hierarchy: Design with a clear CTA button or link, driving to a landing page. Limit distractions or additional links. Example: ‚ÄúUnlock exclusive member benefits‚Äù with a CTA leading to a landing page with a ‚ÄúJoin Now‚Äù button. Follow-up Emails: If no action is taken, send follow-up reminders, highlighting urgency or limited-time offers.
Awareness & Engagement: Post engaging, relevant content that raises awareness about the specific service or product. Use visuals (images, videos) that catch attention quickly. Clear CTA in Posts: Always include a direct link to the landing page with a single action goal, such as ‚ÄúLearn More‚Äù, ‚ÄúJoin Today‚Äù, or ‚ÄúEnroll Now‚Äù. Varied Post Types: Rotate between promotional posts (e.g., ‚ÄúLimited time offer on our educational courses‚Äù) and value-based posts (e.g., testimonials, expert tips) to maintain engagement. Boosted Posts & Ads: Use paid promotions on social platforms to target users based on demographics or past interaction, driving them to the dedicated landing page.
Engagement-driven CTAs: Use CTAs like ‚ÄúGet Started‚Äù or ‚ÄúExplore More‚Äù to reduce friction in the initial click. Banner Ads & Pop-ups: Design targeted ads that appear on key sections of your website. Ensure that these ads promote the single focused CTA (e.g., membership sign-up or course enrollment). Single Goal CTA: Each landing page should have one clear CTA, whether it's "Join Now", "Sign Up", or "Purchase". Avoid clutter and additional links that could distract users from the primary goal. Consistent Messaging: Ensure the landing page reflects the content of the email, social post, or web ad that drove traffic to it, creating a seamless and relevant user experience. Urgency & Value Proposition: Use language that emphasizes urgency (e.g., ‚ÄúLimited time offer‚Äù) and the value proposition (e.g., ‚ÄúExclusive benefits for members‚Äù). Mobile Optimization: Make sure landing pages are mobile-friendly for users arriving via mobile social posts or email.
Track Conversions: Use tools like Google Analytics, UTM codes, or your CRM to monitor which channels (emails, social posts, or web ads) are driving the most traffic and conversions. Abandoned Landing Page Follow-Up: If users visit the landing page but don‚Äôt convert, trigger automated reminder emails or retargeting ads to bring them back, offering added incentives or urgency. Next Steps for Conversions: Once a user converts, deliver a thank you email or confirmation page, guiding them to the next step in their member journey (e.g., onboarding for members, product usage tips).
Direct Email: Send an email to non-members emphasizing the value of membership (e.g., ‚ÄúUnlock exclusive access to resources, discounts, and courses‚Äù). Clear CTA: ‚ÄúJoin Now‚Äù ‚Üí Redirect to membership sign-up landing page. Social Media Post: Post a testimonial or success story from a current member, emphasizing the benefits. Clear CTA: ‚ÄúLearn More‚Äù ‚Üí Redirect to landing page that further explains membership benefits. Website Banner Ad: Place a banner on relevant blog or content pages: ‚ÄúBecome a Member Today and Get Access to Premium Courses‚Äù. Clear CTA: ‚ÄúJoin Now‚Äù ‚Üí Redirect to landing page optimized for membership sign-ups. By focusing on single-action CTAs, and maintaining consistent, clear messaging across all communication channels, this process maximizes the chances of conversion from email, social, and web marketing efforts.

item.description: The Hero Image on the homepage will now support an optional overlay button. This button will be configurable by content editors, allowing them to set the URL, text, style (primary or secondary), and position on the image based on different breakpoints (phone, small tablet, large tablet, and desktop).Scope of the Feature: If there is no URL and Label included in the configuration of the component the hero image area will not be clickable and the render will not render any button UI. It is MarComs responsibility to deliver an images in the correct size and dimensions with non critical information in the area where the button will be positioned. Sizes: 300x350, 600x300,900x300,1200x400 Accepted images are PNG, JPG You can only choose 1 button position, style, URL, and label for all break points. The entire area of the Positioning grid will be clickable and cause the button to hover. The cards part of the feature will also will have their click box expanded to their entire area. Acceptance Criteria: Button Configuration Options: URL: Editors can input the target URL for the button. This URL if empty and the Label is included should default to About-ACC URL Label: Editors can input the display text for the button. Style: Primary Button: Teal blue with white text. Secondary Button: Light grey with black text. ACC Brand Button: ACC Blue with white text ACC Brand Reversed: White with ACC Blue Text Position: Options: 'Left', 'Center', and 'Right'. Position varies depending on the breakpoint (refer to the "Button Position Based on Breakpoint" section below). Button Position Based on Breakpoint: Button Positioning Grid: the Grid inset is 0 0 60px 0 to the full width and eight of the image. 1 rem padding from the edge of its inset image. The hit area of the image should be the entire area. Phone: Aspect Ratio: 3 (width) x 4 (height) Button should size down one step from normal. Uploaded Size: 300w x 350h Grid Layout: 1 column x 3 rows Positioning: Regardless of 'Left', 'Center', or 'Right' setting, the button will be centered in the bottom row. Small Tablet: Aspect Ratio: 2 (width) x 1 (height) Uploaded Size: 600w x 300h Grid Layout: 2 columns x 2 rows Positioning: Left: Bottom-left cell, centered vertically and horizontally. Center: Bottom row, centered horizontally and vertically. Right: Bottom-right cell, centered vertically and horizontally. Large Tablet: Aspect Ratio: 3 (width) x 1 (height) Uploaded Size: 900w x 300h Grid Layout: 3 columns x 2 rows Positioning: Left: Bottom-left cell, centered vertically and horizontally. Center: Bottom center cell, centered horizontally and vertically. Right: Bottom-right cell, centered vertically and horizontally. Desktop: Aspect Ratio: 3 (width) x 1 (height) Uploaded Size: 1200w x 400h Grid Layout: 3 columns x 3 rows Positioning: Left: Bottom-left cell of the last row, centered vertically and horizontally. Center: Bottom center cell of the last row, centered horizontally and vertically. Right: Bottom-right cell of the last row, centered vertically and horizontally. Responsive Behavior: The button's position and size should adjust dynamically based on the device's screen size and aspect ratio. The button should not overlap important text or imagery unless specified in the design guidelines. ( this will be the responsibility of theMarCom to not place critical information in the art in the areas they selected for the button placement. ) Editor Preview: Provide a preview in the CMS where editors can see how the button will look on different breakpoints before publishing. QA Testing Notes: Test button configuration for all breakpoints. Validate button positioning aligns with the specified grid layouts. Verify that styling changes correctly based on editor selection. Test keyboard navigation and screen reader accessibility. Design Reference: See XD Link: https://xd.adobe.com/view/bd608e30-7c5e-45eb-bf89-aab42b492ae3-e833/

item.title: AI Prompt - Conversion Tickets
item.description: Comprehensive Prompt Template for ChatGPT Interaction and Backlog Ticket Creation KSS DocumentationContextual Setup for My Request:I want you to understand and act in the specific context of being a Product Owner on a SCRUM team. Your role is to write backlog tickets for a new feature, considering all aspects typical of a Product Owner's responsibilities in a real-world scenario. I expect the tone and approach of your responses to reflect this role and context. After the prompt please ask up to 3 follow up questions if you any clarifications or supporting details. Here are some key points I want you to consider: SCRUM Methodology Awareness: You should demonstrate a clear understanding of SCRUM principles and practices. Role-Specific Knowledge: As a Product Owner, your focus is on maximizing the value of the product and the work of the development team. Feature-Specific Requirements: The backlog tickets you will create should be for a specific feature, detailed in my request. User-Centric Approach: Emphasize the importance of user stories and prioritize tasks based on user needs and project goals. Communication Style: Your responses should mirror the communication style of a Product Owner - clear, decisive, and oriented towards actionable items. Writing Style: Concise and clear, with a preference for listing items rather than writing out in sentences, to facilitate easy scanning. Project Introduction: Subject Matter: Tech stack - ASP, Vue, HTML, CSS, JavaScript, CMS Sitecore or Sitefinity Internal Terms: [Clarification on terms like ARCHES, PaperCrane, ACC.org, CardioSmart, etc.] ARCHES is a comprehensive front-end design system by the American College of Cardiology. It uses advanced compiler techniques to generate variations that integrate with different frameworks and brands, making it versatile for various ACC products. ARCHES primarily consists of utility classes that offer a modern approach to CSS, focusing on single-style control and separation of responsibilities between HTML and CSS. This system is flexible and adaptable, used across multiple ACC platforms, including ACC.org and CardioSmart, and supports distinct brand styles while maintaining overall coherence. PaperCrane refers to a Component Library specifically designed for Vue.js, a progressive JavaScript framework. This library is utilized in the development of Single Page Applications (SPAs). PaperCrane contains a collection of pre-built Vue components which can be reused across different parts of the enterprise application, enhancing development speed and ensuring UI consistency. ACC.org ACC.org is the official website of the American College of Cardiology. It serves as a comprehensive resource for cardiology professionals, offering a wide range of content including clinical updates, educational materials, guidelines, and information on cardiology conferences and events. The site is designed to support medical professionals in the field of cardiology with the latest scientific research, policy advocacy, and continuous education. It also provides tools and resources for practice support, quality improvement, and patient care in the cardiovascular field. The website caters to the needs of cardiologists, providing them with essential information to advance their knowledge and practice. CardioSmart.org is a patient-centered website created by the American College of Cardiology. It provides comprehensive information about heart health and various cardiac conditions. The site is dedicated to educating patients, offering resources on heart diseases, healthy living tips, and tools to manage cardiac health. It includes topics such as heart disease prevention, treatment options, and lifestyle changes. CardioSmart.org is designed to empower patients with knowledge and tools to actively participate in their own heart care and make informed decisions about their health. Backlog Ticket Structure: Title: A concise, descriptive title for the feature or issue Description: Background: Brief context or background information. Objective: Clear statement of what the ticket aims to achieve. User Story: Format - As a [type of user], I want [an action] so that [a value or result]. Acceptance Criteria: List of conditions that must be met for the ticket to be considered complete. Should be specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART). Dependencies: Any dependencies or prerequisites for the ticket. Checklist for Components: Component Definition: Define the zone, providing a screenshot, requirements from an editor's perspective, and the URL location. Component Identification: IT to identify and isolate the component. Design Implementation: A front-end designer/developer to create an HTML prototype of the component using the Arches design system. Group Grooming: Conduct a group grooming session to identify any additional tickets or tasks necessary to complete the story. Backlog Ticket Creation:Follow the Updated Backlog Ticket Structure provided above to detail your response for this ticket In the Prompt Details below I will detail the information I have for the ticket.Prompt Details: Heading: [Specify the heading for the response.] Introduction: [Brief introduction about the request or the aspect of the project being addressed.] Main Content: [Detailed response or the created backlog ticket based on the structure provided, presented in a concise, list-based format for easy scanning.] Component Name: [A short name of the component to be used in the repo] References or Sources: [If required, mention the need for citations or sources.]

item.description: #acc/ux Before I start this, I want to ask you to "love this for 5 minutes," then you can react.In the act of working with clients, we often take the content documents we are offered, and our reaction to doing IA is to take that content and shoehorn it into UI to satisfy the client.For years and possibly decades, I have taken content documents and shaved off a word or two. However, I have come to realize the immense detriment I have been doing to the strategic approach to content creation by skipping to the UI answer. Instead of merely using 'Styled UI' to reshape, mutate, and hide content, we should focus on enhancing the content to bolster the user experience by solving the underlying issues that users might face with the content that was initially delivered.I have a different opinion on why we shouldn't create wireframes this early in a project. For the sake of speed, we, myself included, often skip the IA step, rushing to return to the client with wireframes. We then cleverly force their content into blocks and hidden areas on the page. The downside of internalizing the IA within the team and applying layouts and UI to content is that it directs our conversations with business lines toward solutions, rather than focusing on improving the content on the site. This undermines the value that IA discussions can bring. Jumping straight to UI wires limits our ability to challenge how we receive and refine raw content. We should at least help them transform it before we start applying UI.I want to ensure there is a moment when clients are encouraged and guided to evaluate the provided content. Content strategists can have the greatest impact by unlocking the potential for more effective and engaging content.Here is an example of what happens when we skip straight to UI. The wireframes react to the content as it is provided. In the team's review of overwhelming content, we responded by using accordions in the UI to hide excess information. This was a superficial fix that masked the issue‚Äîthat the content was too lengthy and not concise. No changes were made to the content itself because we had already hidden it.Now we have introduced a situation where our users are forced into a discovery mode, and we haven't solved the problem that the content was too much or not aligned with the actual goals of the page.To maximize the effectiveness of content, we need to change our approach. Instead of rushing into UI design, we should follow a structured process: Content Evaluation: Review the content before doing any design work. Understand the purpose of the content and whether it aligns with the project's goals. Information Architecture (IA) Application: Use IA to refine, organize, and simplify the content into a logical structure. Ensure that the content is easily navigable and user-friendly. Content Transformation: Apply appropriate hierarchies and organize the text logically. If necessary, split the content across multiple pages to make it more digestible. This should be a word document You can outline that content is either series on the page or is in parallel. Should denote page breaks and how it is wired between pages. Content Presentation: Share the revised content with the client. Encourage them to review it in a Word document format so they can engage with the material and provide feedback. Content Refinement: Based on client feedback, refine the content further. Make sure it is concise, clear, and aligned with the project‚Äôs objectives. UI Design: Only after finalizing the content should we begin designing the UI. At this stage, the content will be well-organized, aligned with user goals, and ready to be integrated into the page layout. By following these steps, we ensure that the content drives the design, not the other way around. This structured approach leads to better user experiences and more effective communication. Where does this go? Should this be another page? What is this content saying? Should we hide this from the user? What is the point of this page? What are the goals, and does this content support them? Let‚Äôs encourage our clients to review the content in a Word document. It‚Äôs important for them to read through the information and share their thoughts. This step is crucial to ensure that the content matches the project‚Äôs goals and is easy for users to understand. As content strategists, we should lead this conversation by presenting our findings and showing our dedication to delivering top-quality content.Only when we have finalized the content can we move on to page designs and work on the UI.

item.title: KSS Documentation
item.description: KSS, or Knyle Style Sheets, is a documentation syntax for CSS that allows developers to create a living style guide from CSS comments. It's structured to be both human-readable and machine-parsable, enabling automated tools to generate style guides from your CSS files. Here's an example of a comprehensive KSS comment block for a CSS stylesheet, including all the main options it can have:/* A button suitable for giving a user a call to action. Style guide: Components.Buttons.Primary :hover - Highlights when hovered. :disabled - Dims the button when it cannot be interacted with. .small - A smaller button for less important actions. .large - A larger button for more important actions. Markup: <button class="btn {{modifier_class}}">Button</button> Modifiers: - .small - A small version of the primary button - .large - A large version of the primary button State classes: - .is-active - Highlights the button as active - .is-disabled - Shows the button as disabled Variables: - $btn-background-color: Color of the button background. - $btn-text-color: Color of the button text. $btn-background-color: #007bff; $btn-text-color: #ffffff; @brand Primary @dependencies - forms.css - grid.css @requires - mixins.css - variables.css @implementations - Web: components/button/button.css - iOS: components/button/button.swift - Android: components/button/button.xml */ .btn { background-color: $btn-background-color; color: $btn-text-color; /* other styles */ } This example includes: Description and Title: A brief description of the component or style and optionally a title. Style Guide Reference: Indicates where in the style guide this component or style belongs. States and Modifiers: Describes different states (:hover, :disabled) and modifiers (.small, .large) that the element can have, including their descriptions. Markup: Provides an HTML snippet as an example of how to implement the described style. Variables: Lists any CSS variables (custom properties) used in the style, including their default values. Brand: Optional brand or category this component belongs to. Dependencies: Other CSS files or assets this component depends on. Requires: Additional resources or files that are required for this component. Implementations: Links or references to implementations of the component in different technologies or platforms. This structured comment allows developers and designers to understand the purpose, usage, and variations of a component at a glance. It can be processed by tools like KSS Node to generate a living style guide, ensuring documentation stays up-to-date with the code.

item.title: Audit of Editorial UI
item.description:
Over time, the content areas of our CMS have seen the implementation of various User Interface (UI) solutions. Often grassroots in origin, these Editorially Created UI elements, composed of inline styles, in-page styles, and JavaScript, present considerable maintenance and update challenges.To manage this tech debt, our bulk conversion process aims to remediate or remove these elements. The goal is to align our UI with the Arches Enterprise Design System, which entails eliminating non-conforming in-page JavaScript and Styles.To facilitate this, we're conducting an audit of the Editorially Created UI components. This audit plays a crucial role in forming a plan that ensures website functionality while addressing unnecessary complexity.This process involves a meticulous examination and subsequent remediation of all editorially integrated links - a prerequisite before launching any audit. Our audit also thoroughly reviews content areas embedded with script and style blocks. Particular attention is given to the returned content scrape, which is systematically converted into a Unicode format that's safe for coding.As part of this procedure, we identify and replace certain patterns, such as "<" and ">", with their equivalent symbols, and transform specific HTML entity codes into spaces and carriage returns, thereby improving block readability. This method allows the team to evaluate readable blocks effectively and discover any "new" patterns, which aids in documenting necessary remediation steps. This systematic approach prepares us for the eventual removal of style and script blocks, creating the necessary tickets or steps as required.Numbered Steps: Begin by running the remediation of all editorially included links that are set to "Save" before initiating the audit. Perform an Audit Report of content areas that contain script and style blocks on the page.
Ensure the returned content scrap is converted into a code-safe Unicode because of the Content Scrape Limitations. Identify and replace specific patterns, such as "<" and ">", with their corresponding symbols. Substitute certain HTML entity codes into space and transform others into carriage returns. Evaluate the now readable blocks after the aforementioned transformations.
Discover any new patterns that emerge from the evaluation, and document the appropriate remediation steps. Finally, create any necessary tickets or steps to prepare for the obliteration of style and script blocks. To make the code more readable, it's crucial to replace certain Unicode characters with their typical representations. Specifically, we'll be dealing with the following conversions: The Unicode for the carriage return, _000D_, should be replaced with a visual marker for carriage returns such as the symbol "‚Üµ". The Unicode for the horizontal tab, _0009_, could be replaced with a few spaces for better visualization. The Unicode for the space, _0020_, can be substituted with a visible space character. The line feed character, represented by the Unicode _000A_, can be swapped with a new line symbol like "‚ê§" to depict line breaks better. The tab character, also represented by _0009_, should be replaced with a few spaces for clarity. Finally, the Unicode for less than and greater than symbols, < and >, can be converted to their actual "<" and ">" symbols. By transforming these Unicode characters into their corresponding visual representations, we significantly enhance the comprehensibility of the document, thus facilitating easier identification of different elements and their spacing.

item.title: Front End Design at the College
item.description:
Frontend development continues to expand as a percentage of project coding to the point that some of our products, such as the clinical applications, are 100% frontend code. Over the past year, I have been putting work together to support a massive shift in how we do frontend and, in the long run, how we develop, support, and release our college software solutions. The most significant issue I continually see in IT is decentralized coding efforts. Decentralization leads to repetitive solutions, inconsistent behaviors, extended regression testing, bloated packages, complicated deployments, and potential code errors as we try to make security patches or upgrades.  Focusing on improving how we execute frontend for the college and not just for a project, I have tackled four pillars.   Unification of design but building for flexibility Shifting to the CFD (component first development ) Creating documentation that is utilized and not just ignored Centralizing everything for everyone The unification of design was the first place I started. "Arches" is the current solution that enforces a Design Opps procedure to streamline requests and deliver a college-wide design system. This design system has two tenants. First, it can replicate its styles influenced by the brand and frameworks from its product space. It now covers QII, ACC, Cardiosmart, and Mobile and can be further scaled. Second is its utility framework that ensures a highly flexible practice to allow countless UI permutations without CSS mutations. Utility styling is also known as "scopeless" styling because you can build out many UI patterns without ever altering the original styles.   https://assets.acc.org/Arches/Latest/docs/Shifting to CFD (component first development) embraces an architecture for our frontend products and alters how we develop. CFD, as a pattern, has been around since 2012 with bootstrap. In its infancy, CFD could only capture minor token UI. Still, with the introduction of javascript models like Web Components, React, Vue CFD can now capture business logic, complicated interface interactions, and data mutations. Vue has been my primary focus as it builds on the collective knowledge of the department. Vue has the capabilities to make obsolete Jquery UI, Pager, Knockout, Angular, JqueryMobile, and many other libraries that are currently in use. IT streamlining to a single dependency allows for universal software patching for frontend security issues. Currently, we are creating documentation that is utilized and not just ignored. As we shift to CFD, we can use Storybook which allows for documentation around a living singular component with artificial data. This type of documentation gives a single point of Design, Development, and QA. The effort on a single element can be attached to countless projects through version control. Centralized development and QA can give us a feasible path to automated unit testing and regression testing. As new projects come online, utilizing the global-version-controlled components would benefit from standards, consistency, and quality control. Preliminary work done with Storybook around a future product under the ACC.org "Home Page Redesign." Projects could include the transcript, CSTool, GL Search, Coveo Search, and FIT Management. Vue 2 component for reference
https://acc-style.github.io/Origami/?path=/story/welcome--to-storybookVue 3 component for all new work
https://assets.acc.org/papercrane/Latest/docs/Centralizing everything for everyone. I have conversations GM, Josh G, and Micheal M, and the great work of Ling C on creating a path forward with using assets.acc.org and also moving the newly used submodule features from GIT within current and future products. Submodules empower the component work to be checked in and out from both the centralized-version-control and from projects, these efforts can be kept in sync. The vision for this project is to be controlled by ACC but utilizable by vendors.
